titleStmt.title: TEI transcription of Mesmerism in Wall Street

msIdentifier.collection: Historical Society of Pennsylvania cartoons and caricatures collection

history.acquisition: This is an artificial collection created over time by HSP staff mostly through donations and purchases of individual prints. It also incorporates previously uncataloged materials collected by the Balch Institute for Ethnic Studies. Some of the 20th century cartoons and drawings were removed from the J. Hampton Moore papers (Collection 1541).

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.
This xml file uses unique entity identifiers, media file identifiers, and collection identifiers in HSP's Digital Library, available at http://digitallibrary.hsp.org.

div.p: At center, Cornelius Vanderbilt sits in a cushioned chair in a library. A woman, identified in the caption as "First Lady Broker" (either Victoria Woodhull or Tennessee Claflin) waves her hands in front of Vanderbilt's face, apparently hypnotizing him. At Vanderbilt's side a second woman, identified in the caption as "Second Lady Broker" (either Woodhull or Claflin), kneels and writes on a piece of paper. The caption implies that Claflin and Woodhull have "mesmerized" Vanderbilt in order to sell them shares of their stocks.
First Lady Broker (entrancing subject.) "THERE, I'VE GOT HIM TO THE POINT NOW. TAKE HIM AT HIS WORD, QUICK."
Commodore V—nd—rb—lt, (murmurs.) "SELL ME ONE THOUSAND SHARES CENTRAL."

div.head: First lady broker (Woodhull or Claflin)
div.p: The two women in this cartoon are clearly intended to be Victoria Woodhull and Tennessee Claflin, sisters who became the first female stock brokers. However, the artist does not provide any visual details to differentiate the two women and indicate which is Woodhull and which is Claflin. Both Claflin and Woodhull, in addition to being stock brokers and equal rights crusaders, worked as spiritualist mediums, clairvoyants (fortune tellers), and magnetic or faith healers; both were advisors to Cornelius Vanderbilt, who became their financial backer in establishing their brokerage firm. It may be that the woman actively "mesmerizing" Vanderbilt is supposed to be Claflin, as she was rumored to have had a romantic relationship with him.

div.head: Second lady broker (Woodhull or Claflin)
div.p: The two women in this cartoon are clearly intended to be Victoria Woodhull and Tennessee Claflin, sisters who became the first female stock brokers. However, the artist does not provide any visual details to differentiate the two women in this cartoon, so it is difficult to say whether the woman sitting by Vanderbilt's side is supposed to be Claflin or Woodhull. The cartoon implies that the two women are controlling Vanderbilt to achieve financial gain.

Cornelius ("Commodore") Vanderbilt made his fortune in the railroad business and in 1872, when this cartoon was published, was the richest man in America. His strong interest in spiritualism put him in touch with sisters Victoria Woodhull and Tennessee Claflin, who became his advisors. He provided silent financial backing for at least two historic firsts: the establishment of Woodhull and Claflin's brokerage firm, which made them the first women stock brokers, and Woodhull's presidential campaign, in which she became the first woman to run for president.
